items.title: OpenAI launches Sora video generation tool in UK amid copyright row
items.summary:
- OpenAI has launched its video generation tool, Sora, in the UK amid a copyright debate.
- Beeban Kidron emphasized the urgency of the copyright discussion, criticizing government plans that favor AI firms.
- The tool allows users to generate videos from simple text prompts, gaining attention from filmmakers and artists.
- Sora was previously launched in the US in December and is also releasing in mainland Europe.
- Users can create short clips with various aesthetic styles and edit them through a storyboard option.
- OpenAI claims compliance with copyright law, using publicly available data for training Sora, despite concerns raised about potential copyright violations.

items.title: A journey through the hyper-political world of microchips
items.summary:
- Extreme ultraviolet (EUV) is crucial for making advanced semiconductor chips, and the only factory producing EUV machines is in the Netherlands.
- EUV machines cost $380 million and require complex logistics for transport, involving 40 freight containers and three cargo planes.
- ASML's machines are not sold to China, impacting its chip production capabilities, making it reliant on older technology.
- TSMC, based in Taiwan, produces 90% of the world's advanced semiconductors, which raises geopolitical concerns amid US-China tensions.
- The US has implemented export controls to limit China's access to advanced chip-making technologies, amid fears of AI and defense implications.
- China produces a significant portion of the world's rare earths, which are essential for semiconductor production, creating a further competitive edge.

items.title: Millions of immigrants to be surveilled under Trump, largest US immigration contractor says
items.summary:
- The Geo Group plans to expand its surveillance of immigrants from 186,000 to potentially up to 450,000 due to demand from the Trump administration.
- The company has contracted with ICE for nearly 20 years and utilizes devices like ankle monitors and facial recognition.
- They are investing $16 million into increasing their inventory of ankle monitors and expect a preference for these devices.
- Executives anticipate a significant increase in monitoring numbers and discussions with ICE regarding expansion of contracts are ongoing.
- The Laken Riley Act may further require electronic monitoring for undocumented immigrants charged with crimes.

items.title: Amazon unveils Ocelot, its first quantum computing chip
items.summary:
- Amazon Web Services (AWS) announced Ocelot, its first-generation quantum computing chip.
- The Ocelot chip can reduce quantum error correction costs by up to 90%.
- Ocelot uses qubits, allowing for multiple states, potentially solving complex problems faster.
- The quantum computing field is heavily invested in by the US and China, with export restrictions in place.
- AWS head Oskar Painter emphasizes that quantum error correction is essential for practical quantum computers.
- Ocelot addresses qubit sensitivity to environmental disturbances, requiring fewer resources for error correction.
- The chip is currently a laboratory prototype, signifying progress towards more capable quantum computers.

items.title: Instagram Reels flooded with violent videos before Meta says it fixed error
items.summary:
- Meta Platforms resolved an error that caused violent and graphic videos to appear in Instagram Reels feeds worldwide.
- Users complained on social media despite activating the 'sensitive content control' setting meant to filter such content.
- Meta apologized for the mistake and did not disclose the reason for the error.
- The incident raised questions about Meta's moderation policies, especially after it scrapped its US fact-checking program across major platforms.
- Violent content is generally prohibited by Meta's policies, which usually lead to removal of such videos unless they serve awareness purposes.
- Meta's reliance on automated moderation tools has increased amidst ongoing criticism regarding user safety and content recommendations.

items.title: Monster Hunter Wilds review – prepare for the most epic fight of your life
items.summary:
- The player battles the Rey Dau, a horned wyvern, in an intense fight using various strategies and techniques.
- Monster Hunter Wilds features a 15-hour story with escalating battles against increasingly powerful creatures.
- The game combines thrilling battles with a beautifully rendered environment, offering an adrenaline-filled experience reminiscent of Dark Souls.
- While the story serves as an introduction to the game, the real enjoyment begins after completing it and exploring the ecosystem and mechanics more deeply.
- Players can engage in teamwork, study monster behaviors and environments, and take part in a robust multiplayer experience.

items.title: YouTube star MrBeast planning investment round that could value company at $5bn
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- MrBeast (Jimmy Donaldson) is planning to raise hundreds of millions, valuing his company at approximately $5bn (£3.9bn).
- He aims to create a holding company for his businesses, including video production, Feastables, and Lunchly, following over $400m in sales last year.
- Current fundraising talks are early, with previous investments from firms like Alpha Wave Global; he has over 368 million YouTube subscribers and has launched successful ventures like Beast Games on Amazon.

items.title: The 15 best games to play on the Nintendo Switch in 2025
items.summary:
- Nintendo's Switch offers a diverse range of games catering to various tastes.
- **Animal Crossing: New Horizons** allows players to build their dream islands and socialize with friends.
- **Fire Emblem: Three Houses** combines tactical role-playing with engaging storytelling.
- **Hades** is an award-winning rogue-like dungeon crawler with dynamic character interactions.
- **Hollow Knight** merges platforming and combat in a hauntingly atmospheric world.
- **Kirby and the Forgotten Land** introduces 3D adventures for the beloved character.
- **Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild** reimagines Hyrule into an expansive open world.
- **Mario Kart 8 Deluxe** enhances the classic racing experience with new features and multiplayer options.
- **Pokémon Legends: Arceus** revamps the Pokémon formula with a focus on exploration.
- **Sea of Stars** pays tribute to classic RPGs with a modern twist.
- **Splatoon 3** provides family-friendly multiplayer mayhem without traditional shooter elements.
- **Stardew Valley** captures the essence of farming and community living.
- **Super Mario Odyssey** delivers creative gameplay and humor in a galaxy-spanning adventure.
- **Super Mario Bros Wonder** brings nostalgic side-scrolling gameplay back with innovative ideas.

items.title: One Man's Fight to Preserve the Last Phone Box in a Norfolk Village
items.summary:
- Derek Harris, an 89-year-old resident of Sharrington, is leading a campaign to save a historic phone box threatened by BT's closure plans.
- The phone box is the last in the area and has been part of the village for over 50 years, facing previous threats of removal.
- Harris argues that the box is vital for locals without mobile phone access, especially in emergencies when mobile signals are unreliable.
- There are regulations that protect phone boxes, especially if they are the last available in an area or frequently used for emergency calls.
- Sharrington’s phone box has seen fewer than 10 calls in the past year, but it is considered a heritage asset and a community resource.
- Harris aims to connect the box to fibre optics as part of a modernization effort before the analog network is phased out in 2027.

items.title: North Korea behind $1.5bn hack of crypto exchange ByBit, says FBI
Trump Cabinet Flunkies Hail Wannabe Caesar and Elon, His Oligarch Pal
items.summary:
- Mary Beard discusses autocracy and its lethal generosity at a nearby event.
- Donald Trump holds his first full cabinet meeting, highlighting a warm and convivial atmosphere.
- Elon Musk attends as a key figure, humorously calling himself 'humble tech support'.
- Musk claims his government efficiency initiative, Doge, will save money but has faced controversies.
- Cabinet consists predominantly of white males, raising questions about diversity.
- Musk admits that mistakes will happen but insists they can be corrected quickly.
- Trump jokingly questions cabinet members about their contentment with Musk's presence.
- Cabinet members praised by Musk include controversial figures such as Pete Hegseth and Robert Kennedy Jr.
- Kennedy downplays a measles outbreak in Texas, causing backlash.
- Overall meeting perceived as a display of authoritarian support and normalization of bullying by Trump.

items.title: Prioritise artists over tech in AI copyright debate, MPs say
items.summary:
- Two cross-party committees of MPs argue for prioritizing fair remuneration for creators over AI training ease.
- They call for transparency about data used to train generative AI models and oppose requiring creators to opt out of data use.
- Caroline Dinenage highlights the concern that AI could exploit creators' work without permission, equating it to allowing theft unless explicitly prohibited.
- The committees demand clearer guidelines on AI's use of copyrighted works and suggest stronger transparency requirements for training data.
- A letter to ministers indicates that without proper regulations, the financial impact on creators could worsen, especially for those already constrained.

items.title: Nvidia to report first earnings since shock debut of Chinese AI DeepSeek
items.summary:
- Nvidia will release its fourth quarter earnings for 2024 on Wednesday, which will be closely monitored by investors.
- Analysts expect the company to retain its position in the AI chip market despite challenges from Microsoft's cancelled data center leases.
- This earnings report will be the first since the introduction of China's DeepSeek AI, which competes with Nvidia's high-end GPUs.
- Some analysts believe DeepSeek may allow competitors like AMD and Intel to gain market share in the AI infrastructure sector.

items.title: Seeking Satoshi: The Mystery Bitcoin Creator review – a documentary so thin it features the creator’s mum
items.summary:
- The identity of Satoshi Nakamoto, the creator of Bitcoin, remains a mystery, explored in Channel 4's documentary.
- The documentary features interviews with various tech figures but fails to uncover significant new information.
- The presenter, Gabriel Gatehouse, mentions the pervasive silence around Satoshi due to potential dangers related to the creator's identity.
- The series diverges into discussions of transhumanism and other related themes rather than focusing solely on Bitcoin.
- Criticism of the documentary includes its lack of depth and over-reliance on previously explored material in other media.

items.title: Netflix’s games were once its best-kept secret – where did it all go wrong?
items.summary:
- Netflix expanded into gaming in 2021 after initial interactive content successes like *Black Mirror: Bandersnatch*.
- The gaming catalog included acclaimed indie games and adaptations like *Spiritfarer* and *Before Your Eyes*.
- The closure of the California blockbuster studio raises concerns about Netflix's commitment to quality gaming.
- Layoffs in gaming divisions and the cancellation of several upcoming games indicate a shift in strategy.
- Netflix aims to focus on narrative games based on its IP, resembling board games, rather than investing in diverse, original content.
- The direction worries stakeholders who hoped for Netflix to innovate within the gaming industry.

items.title: #AltGov: the secret network of federal workers resisting Doge from the inside
items.summary:
- A clandestine network called **#AltGov** is responding to a request from Elon Musk to federal employees to list their activities.
- The group aims to defend public institutions and push back against authoritarianism amidst federal layoffs.
- #AltGov has a presence on **Bluesky**, with over 40 accounts and nearly 95,000 followers on their largest account, **Alt CDC**.
- Historically, the hashtag has roots in the **Trump administration**, and its current iteration has grown significantly in recent weeks.
- Members share strategies through encrypted messaging and collaborate on public-facing information to counter disinformation.
- The network helps federal employees navigate layoffs and develops action plans for civilians to engage with Congress.

items.title: Apple to fix iPhone dictation bug that replaces word ‘racist’ with ‘Trump’
items.summary:
- Apple is addressing a bug in its iPhone dictation tool that substitutes the word 'racist' with 'Trump'.
- The issue was highlighted in a viral TikTok video showing the error occurring during dictation.
- Apple acknowledged the problem and is rolling out a fix, attributing it to phonetic overlap in speech recognition.
- The glitch sparked outrage among conservative commentators who accused big tech of political bias.
- This incident occurred shortly after Apple announced a $500bn investment in the US, which includes AI development and job creation.

items.title: UK universities warned to ‘stress-test’ assessments as 92% of students use AI
items.summary:
- Research shows 92% of students now use generative AI for studies, a significant increase from 66% last year.
- 88% of students reported utilizing tools like ChatGPT for assessments, up from 53% in 2024.
- Report urges universities to review assessments to mitigate AI usage and emphasizes the need for staff retraining on generative AI.

items.title: Warner Bros cancels Wonder Woman video game and closes three studios
items.summary:
- Warner Bros Discovery is closing three video game development studios to boost profitability amid a sluggish market recovery.
- The studios being closed are Player First Games, WB Games San Diego, and Monolith Productions, with development on the Wonder Woman game halted.
- The closures reflect industry challenges as gamers reduce new purchases due to inflation.
- The company will focus on core franchises like Harry Potter, Mortal Kombat, and DC in its restructuring efforts.
- Last month, the former chief of the interactive entertainment unit, David Haddad, departed after 12 years.

items.title: White House says ‘more than 1 million’ federal workers responded to Doge’s ultimatum email – video
items.author: Karoline Leavitt
items.summary:
- More than 1 million US federal employees responded to an email from Elon Musk's Department for Government Efficiency.
- Employees were asked to list five accomplishments from the past week.
- White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt emphasized the need for federal workers to match the pace of President Trump.
- A new email threatens non-responsiveness with potential firing.
- Related articles: [More than 20 Musk staffers resign over Doge’s ‘dismantling of public services’](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/feb/25/musk-doge-employees-resign) and [Trump defends Musk as backlash to federal workers ultimatum grows](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/feb/25/trump-deffends-musk-federal-workers).

items.title: Apple shareholders vote against ending DEI program amid Trump crackdown
items.summary:
- Apple shareholders voted against a proposal to end its diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) program amid pressure from Donald Trump.
- The proposal was put forth by the National Center for Public Policy Research, urging Apple to follow other companies backing away from DEI initiatives.
- Apple's management reaffirmed its commitment to diversity despite legal scrutiny and potential lawsuits related to DEI programs.
- CEO Tim Cook announced a $500 billion investment in the US and the creation of 20,000 jobs over the next five years, seeking to maintain a positive relationship with Trump.
- Cook acknowledged that legal changes might require adjustments to the DEI program while striving for a culture of belonging within the company.
- Apple's 2022 diversity report indicated a workforce makeup of nearly three-fourths white and Asian employees and two-thirds male.

items.title: Slot into a nation of shopkeepers | Brief letters
items.author: Peter Kaan, David Duell, Jennifer Rees, Christine Shuttleworth, Philip Collier
items.summary:
- Arne Slot compared to a provincial butcher and a friendly greengrocer by Barney Ronay.
- Rev Stephen Gardiner's letter suggests claims of the Church of England's demise are overstated despite declining attendance.
- A 28% of over-75s without smartphones face challenges in accessing deals but save time.
- Anecdotes on school report comments highlight different perspectives on education and student behavior.

items.title: ‘I felt nothing but disgust’: Tesla owners vent their anger at Elon Musk
items.summary:
- Tesla sales in Europe plummeted nearly 50% in January 2025, exacerbated by CEO Elon Musk's support for Donald Trump and far-right politics.
- Customers express their outrage, with some planning to sell their cars or using creative means to demonstrate their dissent, like printing anti-Elon stickers.
- Activists in Europe are calling for boycotts of Tesla in response to Musk's political views and actions, citing historical implications and the company's declining reputation.

items.title: Denmark to ban mobile phones in schools and after-school clubs
items.summary:
- Denmark will implement a ban on mobile phones in schools and after-school clubs following a government commission's recommendation.
- All comprehensive primary and lower secondary schools (folkeskole) will be required to be phone-free, impacting children aged 7-17.
- The decision reflects a shift in government policy amid growing concerns about children's digital well-being, with a focus on balancing digital and analogue life.
- The 2023 wellbeing commission report urged restrictions on smartphones for children under 13 and emphasized the negative impacts of excessive screen time.
- The Minister for Children and Education stated that phones and tablets do not belong in schools and began drafting a legislative amendment.

items.title: Tesla sales almost halve in Europe as Musk faces criticism over Trump ties
items.summary:
- Tesla's sales in Europe fell by 45% in January, selling only 9,945 vehicles compared to 18,161 last year.
- Market share decreased from 1.8% to 1% amidst controversies surrounding CEO Elon Musk's political involvement.
- In Germany, sales dropped to 1,277 units, the lowest since July 2021, with a 63% decline in France's sales.
- Musk has been criticized for supporting far-right political parties, impacting consumer perception.
- Overall European market for battery-electric cars grew by 34%, while Tesla's sales decline contrasts with rising competition.

items.title: Cold Wallet review – blackly comic revenge fable goes into crypto’s corrupt heart
items.author: Cutter Hodierne, John Hibey
items.summary:
- Directed by Cutter Hodierne with screenplay by John Hibey, featuring a comedic take on cryptocurrency's dark side.
- Stars Raúl Castillo as Billy, a man struggling with a failing cryptocurrency called Tulip, which drastically loses value after its founder’s rumored death.
- Billy, along with friends Eva and Dom, attempts to confront the real founder to reclaim their losses, exploring themes of greed and human psychology over technology.

items.title: Kate Bush and Damon Albarn among 1,000 artists on silent AI protest album
items.summary:
- Over 1,000 musicians, including Kate Bush and Damon Albarn, released a silent album titled *Is This What We Want?* as a protest against UK government plans allowing AI companies to use copyrighted work without permission.
- The album features recordings from dormant music studios, highlighting the potential threat to artists’ livelihoods due to proposed copyright law changes.
- Profits from the album will be donated to Help Musicians charity, and it coincides with a government consultation on copyright law, which many believe favors big tech companies over creative individuals.

items.title: US court upholds Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes’s conviction
items.summary:
- A US court upheld Elizabeth Holmes’s conviction for defrauding investors out of hundreds of millions while operating Theranos.
- Holmes and Ramesh “Sunny” Balwani's convictions were upheld by a 9th US circuit court of appeals panel in San Francisco.
- Holmes was sentenced to 11 years and three months in 2022, ordered to pay $452 million in restitution, but the penalty is currently on hold.
- Her sentence has been reduced by over two years for good behavior, with expected release in 2032.
- Holmes’s lawyers claimed improper procedures during her trial, but the US attorney affirmed the device did not work as claimed.

items.title: John Oliver on Facebook: ‘An absolute sewer of hatred and misinformation’
items.summary:
- John Oliver criticizes Mark Zuckerberg and Facebook's content moderation on Last Week Tonight.
- He highlights Zuckerberg's shift towards less strict fact-checking rules.
- Oliver discusses the challenges of content moderation and the implications of Section 230.
- He points out the growth of fake news and hate speech on the platform.
- Oliver notes a significant increase in users searching for how to delete their accounts, reflecting dissatisfaction with the platform.

items.title: Apple announces $500bn in US investments over next four years
items.summary:
- Apple to invest $500 billion in the US over four years.
- Investment includes a factory in Texas for AI servers and 20,000 R&D jobs nationwide.
- Previous announcement of $350 billion investment was made in 2018.
- CEO Tim Cook met with President Trump prior to the announcement.
- Apple plans to increase its Advanced Manufacturing Fund from $5 billion to $10 billion.
- A manufacturing academy will be opened in Michigan to offer free courses to firms.

items.title: ‘It’s very lonely’: what are Australia’s university students missing out on?
items.summary:
- Mai, a psychology student, experienced isolation during the transition from in-person to online tutorials amidst the pandemic.
- Many students now find campus life lonely, with fewer attending in-person classes due to work commitments and the convenience of online learning.
- The expectation of a vibrant university life clashes with the reality of reduced social interaction and engagement on campus, leading to a diminished sense of community.
- Australian students are increasingly juggling coursework with jobs, prioritizing work over university social life.
- The trend towards online learning, driven by cost-saving measures, has resulted in larger class sizes and reduced contact hours, impacting educational quality and student satisfaction.

items.title: UK delays plans to regulate AI as ministers seek to align with Trump administration
items.summary:
- UK ministers have postponed the release of a long-awaited AI bill to align with the Trump administration.
- The AI bill was initially expected before Christmas but is now anticipated to be introduced in summer.
- Concerns about advanced AI models posing risks to humanity are driving the need for regulation, yet uncertainty remains due to political changes in the US.
- The UK government has opted not to support international regulatory agreements, instead aiming to attract US AI investment.
- Artists are raising concerns over plans to allow AI companies to use online creative material without copyright permissions.

items.title: ‘I saw taxis as magical things’: Sega’s pop-punk classic Crazy Taxi at 25
items.author: Kenji Kanno
items.summary:
- Crazy Taxi celebrates its 25th anniversary, originally released in arcades.
- Kenji Kanno, the game's director, recalls its impact after a taxi driver in Las Vegas claimed to be the 'real Crazy Taxi'.
- The soundtrack features music by rock band The Offspring, reflecting the energetic vibe of late 90s America.
- Initial skepticism from Sega executives regarding the game's concept due to negative taxi driver stereotypes.
- Kanno aimed to portray taxi drivers positively, making them thrilling and fun, reminiscent of the charm in action-comedy films.
- Crazy Taxi allows players to make rapid decisions as they navigate through a dynamic environment instead of memorizing routes.
- A planned multiplayer mode was cut; however, competitive leaderboards were included.
- Discussion on a potential modern, multiplayer-enabled sequel hinted by Kanno.

items.title: More than 150,000 Canadians sign petition to revoke Musk’s citizenship
items.summary:
- Over 150,000 Canadians signed a petition to revoke Elon Musk’s citizenship due to his alliance with Donald Trump.
- The petition was launched by British Columbia author Qualia Reed and sponsored by NDP member Charlie Angus.
- It accuses Musk of acting against Canada's national interest by advising Trump, who has threatened Canadian sovereignty.
- The petition gathered about 157,000 signatures as of late Sunday, well beyond the required 500 for a formal presentation to Parliament.
- Canada’s House of Commons will resume on 24 March, although the petition’s signing period expired on 20 January.

items.title: Hackers steal $1.5bn from crypto exchange in ‘biggest digital heist ever’
items.summary:
- The cryptocurrency exchange Bybit reported a $1.5bn theft, believed to be the largest digital theft in history.
- An attacker exploited security weaknesses during a routine wallet transfer, stealing Ethereum assets.
- Bybit reassured customers of fund safety and promised to refund affected users regardless of recovery.
- Executive Ben Zhou stated Bybit holds $20bn in assets and can cover losses.
- Post-hack, withdrawal requests surged, leading to potential processing delays.
- Ethereum's price dropped nearly 4% immediately after the news but has stabilized.
- Bybit seeks cybersecurity experts to recover funds, offering a 10% reward for recovered amounts.
- The incident is viewed as a setback for the recovering crypto industry, possibly linked to previous large-scale hacks by groups like Lazarus.

items.title: ‘It could get an orgasm out of a cabbage’: the best vibrators, tested
Don’t gift our work to AI billionaires: Mark Haddon, Michal Rosen and other creatives urge government
items.author: Mark Haddon, Axel Scheffler, Benji Davies, Michael Rosen, Ged Adamson, Simona Ciraolo, Momoko Abe, Chris Haughton, Susie Alegre
items.summary:
- Over 2,000 creatives signed a letter urging the UK government to maintain copyright protections amid rising AI usage.
- The letter criticizes proposed copyright rule relaxations that could harm the income of artists and writers.
- Notable signatories include Mark Haddon and Michael Rosen, who emphasize the threat to creative culture and livelihoods.
- Concerns raised over the detrimental effects on diversity in creative industries, especially for BAME authors and illustrators.
- Campaigners warn that generative AI lacks true creativity and will exacerbate existing inequalities in the creative sector.

items.title: Want to stay sane? Try switching off your news alerts
items.author: Eva Wiseman
items.summary:
- The author discusses the mental strain of constant news alerts and information overload.
- Turning off breaking news alerts can help manage anxiety and prevent feeling overwhelmed.
- Finding a balance between staying informed and not being consumed by news is crucial for mental health.

items.title: iPhone designer still asks: ‘I wonder what Steve Jobs would do?’ – despite being told not to
items.author: Sir Jony Ive
items.summary:
- Sir Jony Ive, Apple's designer, frequently wonders about Steve Jobs' decisions despite Jobs advising him not to.
- He revealed this during an interview on BBC Radio 4’s *Desert Island Discs*.
- Ive worked closely with Jobs, who returned to Apple in 1997, and found his understanding of design remarkable.
- He believes Jobs’ demanding reputation is unfair, emphasizing the need for clarity in creativity.
- Ive expressed concerns over technology's impact on creativity and his responsibilities regarding the iPhone's negative effects.
- He voiced mixed feelings about AI, recognizing both its potential and the need for caution in its development.

items.title: Creative industries are among the UK’s crown jewels – and AI is out to steal them
items.author: John Naughton
items.summary:
- Recent developments reveal that American tech companies are increasingly entwined with government, raising concerns in Europe about regulation and copyright.
- The UK's AI Safety Institute has been rebranded to focus on security, which symbolizes a shift towards facilitating US tech interests over creative sector protections.
- Proposed changes to UK copyright laws could allow tech firms to train AI models on copyrighted materials without permission or compensation, undermining the creative industries worth £124.6bn to the UK economy.
- A report warns that unregulated AI use could harm the UK's thriving creative sector instead of fostering economic growth, emphasizing the need for sound public policy that respects creative rights.

items.title: ‘The bot asked me four times a day how I was feeling’: is tracking everything actually good for us?
‘We’re clearly heading towards collapse’: why the Murdoch empire is about to go bang
items.summary:
- Recent revelations expose the dysfunction and despair within the Murdoch family amid legal battles over inheritance.
- Rupert Murdoch faced criticism for attempting to disinherit three out of four of his eldest children, leading to a lawsuit.
- A Nevada court ruled against Rupert, stating he acted in 'bad faith', with appeals ongoing.
- The family dispute has economic implications for a media empire valued at $43 billion, potentially altering its influence in politics.
- James Murdoch publicly criticized his father as a 'misogynist' in a recent interview highlighting family tensions.
- Legal challenges include a defamation claim against Fox News and questioning the profitability of Murdoch's UK newspaper assets.

items.title: Crypto and big tech’s backing pays off as Trump makes tech-friendly moves
items.summary:
- US tech companies' investments in support of Donald Trump yield favorable regulatory changes.
- Trump's administration issues deregulation initiatives benefiting crypto, AI, and social media firms.
- Elon Musk, benefiting from his significant donations, plays a central role in the new administration's tech-friendly policies.
- The SEC plans to dismiss a lawsuit against Coinbase after it donated $1 million to Trump's inaugural fund.
- Regulatory safeguards on AI are being cut, echoing complaints from Silicon Valley about over-regulation.
- Trump signs an executive order aimed at reducing federal regulations impacting the tech industry.

items.title: Social media bans for teens: Australia has passed one, should other countries follow suit?
items.summary:
- Australia has passed legislation banning access to social media for under-16s, effective December 2025.
- Concerns about children’s safety online are driving discussions for similar bans in other countries, including the UK.
- Support for the ban has been voiced by major figures, including Bill Gates.
- The law requires social media networks to implement age-assurance methods, which may include facial recognition technology.
- A recent poll showed 75% public support in the UK for banning under-16s from social media.
- Critics argue that bans may not solve the underlying problems, as harmful content and actors may migrate to other networks and platforms.
- There is uncertainty about the effectiveness of technology used to enforce age restrictions and ongoing debates about the mental health implications of social media usage among teens.

items.title: How to navigate apps, from checking safety to remembering passwords
items.author: Samuel Gibbs
items.summary:
- Organizations increasingly require app downloads for accessing services and deals.
- Tips for managing phone storage include deleting unused apps and moving media to cloud services.
- Ensure app safety by downloading only from official app stores and verifying developer authenticity.
- Public wifi can be used for app downloads but with caution; trusted networks recommended.
- Use password managers like 1Password or Bitwarden to securely manage passwords, and implement two-step verification.
- Keep your phone and apps updated to avoid security risks and improve functionality.
- Tips for battery management include carrying backup chargers and using power save modes.

items.title: ‘The tyranny of apps’: those without smartphones are unfairly penalised, say campaigners
items.summary:
- Millions in the UK without access to smartphones are being penalised, affecting their access to discounts and services.
- 8% of people aged 16+ do not own a smartphone, translating to around 4.5 million individuals, with 28% of those aged 75+ lacking one.
- Retailers like Lidl and Asda limit discounts through their apps, which are inaccessible to those without smartphones.
- The parking sector has pushed for app-only payment systems, complicating access for many elderly citizens.
- Events increasingly require app-based tickets, excluding those who cannot use smartphones from attending.
- Fast food chains like McDonald’s and Subway offer exclusive discounts through their apps, disadvantaging non-app users.

items.title: Filter trouble? Why audiologists worry noise-cancelling tech may impair hearing skills
items.summary:
- Noise-cancelling headphones are valued for reducing background noise but may impair auditory skills.
- Audiologists report an increase in adults with auditory processing issues, not due to ear health but brain function.
- Concerns arise that excessive use of noise-cancelling tech could weaken the brain’s ability to process multiple sound sources.
- The condition known as auditory processing disorder (APD) traditionally diagnosed in children is now seen in adults, possibly due to technology use.
- Lack of scientific evidence linking headphones to APD raises the need for further studies, especially on impacts of long-term use in younger users.
- APD affects about 3-5% of children, linked to issues like low birth weight and chronic ear infections.
- Experts suggest that while benefits of noise-cancelling are recognized, risks warrant more in-depth research, especially regarding impact on children’s auditory skills.

items.title: Every hour children spend on screens raises chance of myopia, study finds
items.summary:
- Researchers found each hour on screens increases the risk of myopia in children.
- Involvement of 335,524 participants across 45 studies reveals a 21% higher risk of myopia with an extra hour of screen time.
- Risks rise steeply with daily screen time; 54% higher odds for those already myopic with additional hour of screen use.
- Study suggests a potential safety threshold for screen use below one hour daily.
- Limitations include reliance on self-reports and the need for further evidence to understand causation.

items.title: UK Parents Sue TikTok Over Alleged Wrongful Deaths of Children
items.summary:
- Four British parents are suing TikTok for the alleged wrongful deaths of their children linked to the "blackout challenge."
- The lawsuit claims their children died in 2022 due to this viral trend that first circulated in 2021.
- Parents express skepticism about TikTok's claim of deleting their children's data following their deaths, suggesting it was done too quickly.
- TikTok's response implies legal requirements dictate data retention; however, parents are concerned about access to their children's data.
- Under GDPR, parents of children under 13 should have rights to access their children’s accounts, but struggles continue.
- The Online Safety Act, set to take effect this year, will require platforms to protect children from harmful content.

items.title: Samsung Galaxy S25 review: the smallest top-tier Android left
items.summary:
- The Galaxy S25 is the smallest and cheapest of Samsung’s new S25 line, priced at £799 ($800/A$1,399).
- It features a 6.2-inch screen, a Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Elite processor, and three cameras (50MP main, 12MP ultrawide, 10MP 3x telephoto).
- The phone has software upgrades with AI tools and seven years of software support, making it a compelling option despite its small size.
